text: Edmund ’s account of Fanny ’s disposition he could believe to be just ; he supposed she had all those feelings , but he must consider it as very unfortunate that she _ had _ ; for , less willing than his son to trust to the future , he could not help fearing that if such very long allowances of time and habit were necessary for her , she might not have persuaded herself into receiving his addresses properly before the young man ’s inclination for paying them were over .

text_tokenized: I could not but see that Mr. Crawford amused himself in gallantries which did mean nothing . ”

text: “ Ah !
text_tokenized: “ Ah !

text: I can not deny it .
text_tokenized: I can not deny it .

text: He has now and then been a sad flirt , and cared very little for the havoc he might be making in young ladies ’ affections .
text_tokenized: He has now and then been a sad flirt , and cared very little for the havoc he might be making in young ladies ’ affections .

text: I have often scolded him for it , but it is his only fault ; and there is this to be said , that very few young ladies have any affections worth caring for .
text_tokenized: I have often scolded him for it , but it is his only fault ; and there is this to be said , that very few young ladies have any affections worth caring for .

text: And then , Fanny , the glory of fixing one who has been shot at by so many ; of having it in one ’s power to pay off the debts of one ’s sex !
text_tokenized: And then , Fanny , the glory of fixing one who has been shot at by so many ; of having it in one ’s power to pay off the debts of one ’s sex !

text: Oh !
text_tokenized: Oh !

text: I am sure it is not in woman ’s nature to refuse such a triumph . ”
text_tokenized: I am sure it is not in woman ’s nature to refuse such a triumph . ”

text: Fanny shook her head .
text_tokenized: Fanny shook her head .

text: “ I can not think well of a man who sports with any woman ’s feelings ; and there may often be a great deal more suffered than a stander - by can judge of . ”
text_tokenized: “ I can not think well of a man who sports with any woman ’s feelings ; and there may often be a great deal more suffered than a stander - by can judge of . ”

text: “ I do not defend him .
text_tokenized: “ I do not defend him .

text: I leave him entirely to your mercy , and when he has got you at Everingham , I do not care how much you lecture him .
text_tokenized: I leave him entirely to your mercy , and when he has got you at Everingham , I do not care how much you lecture him .

text: But this I will say , that his fault , the liking to make girls a little in love with him , is not half so dangerous to a wife ’s happiness as a tendency to fall in love himself , which he has never been addicted to .
text_tokenized: But this I will say , that his fault , the liking to make girls a little in love with him , is not half so dangerous to a wife ’s happiness as a tendency to fall in love himself , which he has never been addicted to .

text: And I do seriously and truly believe that he is attached to you in a way that he never was to any woman before ; that he loves you with all his heart , and will love you as nearly for ever as possible .
text_tokenized: And I do seriously and truly believe that he is attached to you in a way that he never was to any woman before ; that he loves you with all his heart , and will love you as nearly for ever as possible .

text: If any man ever loved a woman for ever , I think Henry will do as much for you . ”
text_tokenized: If any man ever loved a woman for ever , I think Henry will do as much for you . ”

text: Fanny could not avoid a faint smile , but had nothing to say .
text_tokenized: Fanny could not avoid a faint smile , but had nothing to say .

text: “ I can not imagine Henry ever to have been happier , ” continued Mary presently , “ than when he had succeeded in getting your brother ’s commission . ”
text_tokenized: “ I can not imagine Henry ever to have been happier , ” continued Mary presently , “ than when he had succeeded in getting your brother ’s commission . ”

text: She had made a sure push at Fanny ’s feelings here .

text: The Admiral hates trouble , and scorns asking favours ; and there are so many young men ’s claims to be attended to in the same way , that a friendship and energy , not very determined , is easily put by .

text: The recollection of what had been done for William was always the most powerful disturber of every decision against Mr. Crawford ; and she sat thinking deeply of it till Mary , who had been first watching her complacently , and then musing on something else , suddenly called her attention by saying : “ I should like to sit talking with you here all day , but we must not forget the ladies below , and so good - bye , my dear , my amiable , my excellent Fanny , for though we shall nominally part in the breakfast - parlour , I must take leave of you here .
text_tokenized: The recollection of what had been done for William was always the most powerful disturber of every decision against Mr. Crawford ; and she sat thinking deeply of it till Mary , who had been first watching her complacently , and then musing on something else , suddenly called her attention by saying : “ I should like to sit talking with you here all day , but we must not forget the ladies below , and so good - bye , my dear , my amiable , my excellent Fanny , for though we shall nominally part in the breakfast - parlour , I must take leave of you here .

text: And I do take leave , longing for a happy reunion , and trusting that when we meet again , it will be under circumstances which may open our hearts to each other without any remnant or shadow of reserve . ” A very , very kind embrace , and some agitation of manner , accompanied these words .

text: “ I shall see your cousin in town soon : he talks of being there tolerably soon ; and Sir Thomas , I dare say , in the course of the spring ; and your eldest cousin , and the Rushworths , and Julia , I am sure of meeting again and again , and all but you .
text_tokenized: “ I shall see your cousin in town soon : he talks of being there tolerably soon ; and Sir Thomas , I dare say , in the course of the spring ; and your eldest cousin , and the Rushworths , and Julia , I am sure of meeting again and again , and all but you .

text: I have two favours to ask , Fanny : one is your correspondence .
text_tokenized: I have two favours to ask , Fanny : one is your correspondence .

text: You must write to me .
text_tokenized: You must write to me .

text: And the other , that you will often call on Mrs. Grant , and make her amends for my being gone .
text_tokenized: And the other , that you will often call on Mrs. Grant , and make her amends for my being gone .

text: ” The first , at least , of these favours Fanny would rather not have been asked ; but it was impossible for her to refuse the correspondence ; it was impossible for her even not to accede to it more readily than her own judgment authorised .

text: There was no resisting so much apparent affection .

text_tokenized: Her disposition was peculiarly calculated to value a fond treatment , and from having hitherto known so little of it , she was the more overcome by Miss Crawford ’s .

text: It was over , and she had escaped without reproaches and without detection .
text_tokenized: It was over , and she had escaped without reproaches and without detection .

text: Her secret was still her own ; and while that was the case , she thought she could resign herself to almost everything .

text: Henry Crawford came and sat some time with them ; and her spirits not being previously in the strongest state , her heart was softened for a while towards him , because he really seemed to feel .

text: Quite unlike his usual self , he scarcely said anything .
text_tokenized: Quite unlike his usual self , he scarcely said anything .

text: Mr. Crawford gone , Sir Thomas ’s next object was that he should be missed ; and he entertained great hope that his niece would find a blank in the loss of those attentions which at the time she had felt , or fancied , an evil .
text_tokenized: Mr. Crawford gone , Sir Thomas ’s next object was that he should be missed ; and he entertained great hope that his niece would find a blank in the loss of those attentions which at the time she had felt , or fancied , an evil .

text: She had tasted of consequence in its most flattering form ; and he did hope that the loss of it , the sinking again into nothing , would awaken very wholesome regrets in her mind .
text_tokenized: She had tasted of consequence in its most flattering form ; and he did hope that the loss of it , the sinking again into nothing , would awaken very wholesome regrets in her mind .

text_tokenized: He hardly knew whether there were any difference in her spirits or not .

text: She was always so gentle and retiring that her emotions were beyond his discrimination .

text: What chiefly surprised Edmund was , that Crawford ’s sister , the friend and companion who had been so much to her , should not be more visibly regretted .
text_tokenized: What chiefly surprised Edmund was , that Crawford ’s sister , the friend and companion who had been so much to her , should not be more visibly regretted .

text: He wondered that Fanny spoke so seldom of _ her _ , and had so little voluntarily to say of her concern at this separation .
text_tokenized: He wondered that Fanny spoke so seldom of _ her _ , and had so little voluntarily to say of her concern at this separation .

text_tokenized: Alas !

text: If she could have believed Mary ’s future fate as unconnected with Mansfield as she was determined the brother ’s should be , if she could have hoped her return thither to be as distant as she was much inclined to think his , she would have been light of heart indeed ; but the more she recollected and observed , the more deeply was she convinced that everything was now in a fairer train for Miss Crawford ’s marrying Edmund than it had ever been before .
text_tokenized: If she could have believed Mary ’s future fate as unconnected with Mansfield as she was determined the brother ’s should be , if she could have hoped her return thither to be as distant as she was much inclined to think his , she would have been light of heart indeed ; but the more she recollected and observed , the more deeply was she convinced that everything was now in a fairer train for Miss Crawford ’s marrying Edmund than it had ever been before .

text: On his side the inclination was stronger , on hers less equivocal .
text_tokenized: On his side the inclination was stronger , on hers less equivocal .

text: His objections , the scruples of his integrity , seemed all done away , nobody could tell how ; and the doubts and hesitations of her ambition were equally got over — and equally without apparent reason .
text_tokenized: His objections , the scruples of his integrity , seemed all done away , nobody could tell how ; and the doubts and hesitations of her ambition were equally got over — and equally without apparent reason .

text: It could only be imputed to increasing attachment .
text_tokenized: It could only be imputed to increasing attachment .

text: His good and her bad feelings yielded to love , and such love must unite them .
text_tokenized: His good and her bad feelings yielded to love , and such love must unite them .

text: He was to go to town as soon as some business relative to Thornton Lacey were completed — perhaps within a fortnight ; he talked of going , he loved to talk of it ; and when once with her again , Fanny could not doubt the rest .
text_tokenized: He was to go to town as soon as some business relative to Thornton Lacey were completed — perhaps within a fortnight ; he talked of going , he loved to talk of it ; and when once with her again , Fanny could not doubt the rest .

text: Her acceptance must be as certain as his offer ; and yet there were bad feelings still remaining which made the prospect of it most sorrowful to her , independently , she believed , independently of self .

text: In their very last conversation , Miss Crawford , in spite of some amiable sensations , and much personal kindness , had still been Miss Crawford ; still shewn a mind led astray and bewildered , and without any suspicion of being so ; darkened , yet fancying itself light .

text: Fanny believed there was scarcely a second feeling in common between them ; and she may be forgiven by older sages for looking on the chance of Miss Crawford ’s future improvement as nearly desperate , for thinking that if Edmund ’s influence in this season of love had already done so little in clearing her judgment , and regulating her notions , his worth would be finally wasted on her even in years of matrimony . Experience might have hoped more for any young people so circumstanced , and impartiality would not have denied to Miss Crawford ’s nature that participation of the general nature of women which would lead her to adopt the opinions of the man she loved and respected as her own .
text_tokenized: Fanny believed there was scarcely a second feeling in common between them ; and she may be forgiven by older sages for looking on the chance of Miss Crawford ’s future improvement as nearly desperate , for thinking that if Edmund ’s influence in this season of love had already done so little in clearing her judgment , and regulating her notions , his worth would be finally wasted on her even in years of matrimony . Experience might have hoped more for any young people so circumstanced , and impartiality would not have denied to Miss Crawford ’s nature that participation of the general nature of women which would lead her to adopt the opinions of the man she loved and respected as her own .

text: But as such were Fanny ’s persuasions , she suffered very much from them , and could never speak of Miss Crawford without pain . Sir Thomas , meanwhile , went on with his own hopes and his own observations , still feeling a right , by all his knowledge of human nature , to expect to see the effect of the loss of power and consequence on his niece ’s spirits , and the past attentions of the lover producing a craving for their return ; and he was soon afterwards able to account for his not yet completely and indubitably seeing all this , by the prospect of another visitor , whose approach he could allow to be quite enough to support the spirits he was watching .
text_tokenized: But as such were Fanny ’s persuasions , she suffered very much from them , and could never speak of Miss Crawford without pain . text: William had obtained a ten days ’ leave of absence , to be given to Northamptonshire , and was coming , the happiest of lieutenants , because the latest made , to shew his happiness and describe his uniform .

text: So the uniform remained at Portsmouth , and Edmund conjectured that before Fanny had any chance of seeing it , all its own freshness and all the freshness of its wearer ’s feelings must be worn away .

text: But Mrs. Norris wanted to persuade her that Fanny could be very well spared—_she _ being ready to give up all her own time to her as requested — and , in short , could not really be wanted or missed .
text_tokenized: But Mrs. Norris wanted to persuade her that Fanny could be very well spared—_she _ being ready to give up all her own time to her as requested — and , in short , could not really be wanted or missed .

text: “ That may be , sister , ” was all Lady Bertram ’s reply . “ I dare say you are very right ; but I am sure I shall miss her very much . ”
text_tokenized: “ That may be , sister , ” was all Lady Bertram ’s reply . “ I dare say you are very right ; but I am sure I shall miss her very much . ”

text: The next step was to communicate with Portsmouth .
text_tokenized: The next step was to communicate with Portsmouth .

text: Fanny wrote to offer herself ; and her mother ’s answer , though short , was so kind — a few simple lines expressed so natural and motherly a joy in the prospect of seeing her child again , as to confirm all the daughter ’s views of happiness in being with her — convincing her that she should now find a warm and affectionate friend in the “ mama ” who had certainly shewn no remarkable fondness for her formerly ; but this she could easily suppose to have been her own fault or her own fancy .
text_tokenized: Fanny wrote to offer herself ; and her mother ’s answer , though short , was so kind — a few simple lines expressed so natural and motherly a joy in the prospect of seeing her child again , as to confirm all the daughter ’s views of happiness in being with her — convincing her that she should now find a warm and affectionate friend in the “ mama ” who had certainly shewn no remarkable fondness for her formerly ; but this she could easily suppose to have been her own fault or her own fancy .

text: She had probably alienated love by the helplessness and fretfulness of a fearful temper , or been unreasonable in wanting a larger share than any one among so many could deserve .
text_tokenized: She had probably alienated love by the helplessness and fretfulness of a fearful temper , or been unreasonable in wanting a larger share than any one among so many could deserve .

text: Now , when she knew better how to be useful , and how to forbear , and when her mother could be no longer occupied by the incessant demands of a house full of little children , there would be leisure and inclination for every comfort , and they should soon be what mother and daughter ought to be to each other .
text_tokenized: Now , when she knew better how to be useful , and how to forbear , and when her mother could be no longer occupied by the incessant demands of a house full of little children , there would be leisure and inclination for every comfort , and they should soon be what mother and daughter ought to be to each other .

text: William was almost as happy in the plan as his sister .
text_tokenized: William was almost as happy in the plan as his sister .

text: It would be the greatest pleasure to him to have her there to the last moment before he sailed , and perhaps find her there still when he came in from his first cruise .
text_tokenized: It would be the greatest pleasure to him to have her there to the last moment before he sailed , and perhaps find her there still when he came in from his first cruise .

text: And besides , he wanted her so very much to see the Thrush before she went out of harbour — the Thrush was certainly the finest sloop in the service — and there were several improvements in the dockyard , too , which he quite longed to shew her .
text_tokenized: And besides , he wanted her so very much to see the Thrush before she went out of harbour — the Thrush was certainly the finest sloop in the service — and there were several improvements in the dockyard , too , which he quite longed to shew her .

text: He did not scruple to add that her being at home for a while would be a great advantage to everybody .
text_tokenized: He did not scruple to add that her being at home for a while would be a great advantage to everybody .

text: “ I do not know how it is , ” said he ; “ but we seem to want some of your nice ways and orderliness at my father ’s .
text_tokenized: “ I do not know how it is , ” said he ; “ but we seem to want some of your nice ways and orderliness at my father ’s .

text: The house is always in confusion .
text_tokenized: The house is always in confusion .

text: You will set things going in a better way , I am sure .
text_tokenized: You will set things going in a better way , I am sure .

text: You will tell my mother how it all ought to be , and you will be so useful to Susan , and you will teach Betsey , and make the boys love and mind you .
text_tokenized: You will tell my mother how it all ought to be , and you will be so useful to Susan , and you will teach Betsey , and make the boys love and mind you .

text: How right and comfortable it will all be ! ”
text_tokenized: How right and comfortable it will all be ! ”

text: By the time Mrs. Price ’s answer arrived , there remained but a very few days more to be spent at Mansfield ; and for part of one of those days the young travellers were in a good deal of alarm on the subject of their journey , for when the mode of it came to be talked of , and Mrs. Norris found that all her anxiety to save her brother - in - law ’s money was vain , and that in spite of her wishes and hints for a less expensive conveyance of Fanny , they were to travel post ; when she saw Sir Thomas actually give William notes for the purpose , she was struck with the idea of there being room for a third in the carriage , and suddenly seized with a strong inclination to go with them , to go and see her poor dear sister Price .
text_tokenized: By the time Mrs. Price ’s answer arrived , there remained but a very few days more to be spent at Mansfield ; and for part of one of those days the young travellers were in a good deal of alarm on the subject of their journey , for when the mode of it came to be talked of , and Mrs. Norris found that all her anxiety to save her brother - in - law ’s money was vain , and that in spite of her wishes and hints for a less expensive conveyance of Fanny , they were to travel post ; when she saw Sir Thomas actually give William notes for the purpose , she was struck with the idea of there being room for a third in the carriage , and suddenly seized with a strong inclination to go with them , to go and see her poor dear sister Price .

text: So her poor dear sister Price was left to all the disappointment of her missing such an opportunity , and another twenty years ’ absence , perhaps , begun . Edmund ’s plans were affected by this Portsmouth journey , this absence of Fanny ’s .

text: He too had a sacrifice to make to Mansfield Park as well as his aunt .
text_tokenized: He too had a sacrifice to make to Mansfield Park as well as his aunt .

text: He had intended , about this time , to be going to London ; but he could not leave his father and mother just when everybody else of most importance to their comfort was leaving them ; and with an effort , felt but not boasted of , he delayed for a week or two longer a journey which he was looking forward to with the hope of its fixing his happiness for ever .

text: It made the substance of one other confidential discourse about Miss Crawford ; and Fanny was the more affected from feeling it to be the last time in which Miss Crawford ’s name would ever be mentioned between them with any remains of liberty .

text: Lady Bertram had been telling her niece in the evening to write to her soon and often , and promising to be a good correspondent herself ; and Edmund , at a convenient moment , then added in a whisper , “ And _ I _ shall write to you , Fanny , when I have anything worth writing about , anything to say that I think you will like to hear , and that you will not hear so soon from any other quarter . ”

text: it was not till it was over that she knew he was giving her the affectionate farewell of a brother . All this passed overnight , for the journey was to begin very early in the morning ; and when the small , diminished party met at breakfast , William and Fanny were talked of as already advanced one stage .
